next_steps.note: "Brainstorm potential themes or subjects for the poetry (e.g., nature, love, loss, social commentary). Add 3-5 to the 'Ideas' list.",
"Research contemporary poets and poetry styles to identify potential inspiration. Document 2-3 poets/styles in 'Ideas'.",
"Draft a first poem – aim for a short, free-verse piece, focusing on imagery. Add '[Draft 1 - Title]' to 'Progress' once completed.",
"Define a project scope. How many poems will this project encompass? Add this number to 'Ideas'.",
"Create a 'Revision Notes' section within the board to capture feedback and ideas for improvement on draft poems."
"Brainstorm 3 potential themes or subjects for the next set of poems, documenting ideas in the 'Ideas' list.",
"Draft a single poem (any length) focusing on one of the brainstormed themes, adding it to 'Progress' as a first draft.",
"Review the 'Ideas' list and prioritize the top 2 most compelling ideas for further development, noting reasons for prioritization.",
"Identify one potential resource (e.g., poet to read, writing prompt website, anthology) to inspire new work and add it to 'Ideas'.",
"Define the criteria for 'completion' of this poetry project (e.g., number of poems, specific style, submission goal) and document in 'Progress'."
"Choose one of the 'Ideas' (Found Poetry, Poetry Pairing, Micro-Poetry, Poetry Swap, or Prompt Jar) and dedicate 30 minutes to *starting* that exercise today.",
"Create a simple document (text file, note, etc.) titled 'Poetry Ideas - In Progress' to track which exercises are being attempted and any initial thoughts.",
"Review the 14 pending next steps (mentioned in 'Additional Context') and prioritize the top 3 based on feasibility and potential impact.",
"Set a realistic goal for poetry output this week (e.g., complete 3 micro-poems, finish one found poem, or participate in one poetry swap).",
"Brainstorm potential sources for text snippets if opting for the 'Found Poetry' exercise (newspapers, magazines, books, websites)."

"Identify a writing partner for a 'Poetry Swap' and agree on a timeframe for exchanging first drafts (e.g., within 5 days).",
"Commit to writing three micro-poems (haiku, senryu, or three-line poems) today, focusing on capturing a single image or feeling in each."
"Choose one poetry exercise from the 'Ideas' list (Found Poetry, Poetry Pairing, Micro-Poetry, Poetry Swap, or Prompt Jar) and commit to spending 30 minutes on it tomorrow.",
"Create a digital document (or physical notebook) dedicated solely to this poetry project, to collect ideas, drafts, and inspirations.",
"Identify three potential sources for Found Poetry (e.g., a newspaper, a novel, a website) and skim them for interesting phrases or sentences.",
"Reach out to a friend or writing group member and propose a 'Poetry Swap' for initial drafts, scheduling a feedback exchange for next week.",
"Brainstorm at least 10 potential prompts to include in a 'Poetry Prompt Jar' (or a digital equivalent) and write them down."
"Select one 'Micro-Poetry Challenge' prompt (haiku, senryu, etc.) and commit to writing three poems using that form today.",
"Gather 5-10 images for an 'Image Prompt' collection and write a single line/phrase poem fragment inspired by the first image.",
"Choose a poem you admire and begin the 'Poetry Remix' challenge by identifying and listing the nouns and verbs in the first stanza.",
"Dedicate 15 minutes to a 'Sensory Detail' session focusing on a single object in your immediate surroundings and jot down at least 10 descriptive details.",
"Schedule a 'Poetry Swap' with a friend or writing partner and agree on a date to exchange first drafts for feedback within the next week."

"Start the 'Micro-Poetry Challenge' – commit to writing one haiku today.",

```json
"Begin the 'Found Poetry' exercise: Spend 30 minutes collecting text snippets from at least three different sources (newspapers, books, online) and attempt to create a short poem.",
"Start a 'Micro-Poetry' series: Commit to writing one haiku or three-line poem today, focusing on a simple observation or feeling.",
"Create a basic 'Poetry Prompt Jar': Write down at least 5 creative writing prompts on slips of paper and place them in a jar or container.",
"Gather images for the 'Image Prompt' Collection: Find 5-10 compelling images online or in magazines and save them to a digital mood board (Pinterest, Google Docs).",
"Select a poem to use for the 'Poetry Remix' challenge: Choose a relatively short poem you admire and prepare to rewrite it, changing only the nouns and verbs."

ideas.note: "**Experiment with Found Poetry:** Collect snippets of text from various sources (newspapers, books, online articles) and rearrange them to create a poem. This circumvents initial drafting hurdles and encourages unique perspectives.",

"**'Poetry Pairing' Exercise:** Select a painting, photograph, or piece of music and write a poem *inspired* by it. Focus on capturing the mood, texture, or narrative suggested by the external stimulus.",

"**Micro-Poetry Challenge:** Commit to writing a series of very short poems (e.g., haiku, senryu, tanka, or three-line poems) daily for a week. This builds momentum and encourages concise, impactful writing.",
"**'Poetry Swap' with a Friend:** Exchange first drafts with a friend or fellow writer for constructive feedback. Focus feedback requests on specific areas like imagery, rhythm, or clarity.",

"**Develop a 'Poetry Prompt Jar':** Write down a variety of creative writing prompts (single words, phrases, scenarios, or 'what if' questions) on slips of paper and draw one each time you want to start a new poem. This eliminates decision fatigue and introduces unexpected inspiration."

"**Dedicated 'Sensory Detail' Session:** Spend 30 minutes actively *observing* your surroundings (a room, a park, a piece of fruit) and jot down specific sensory details (sight, sound, smell, taste, touch). Then, use these details as the foundation for a short poem, focusing on creating a vivid experience for the reader.",

"**'Poetry Remix' Challenge:** Choose a poem you admire.  Rewrite it, changing *only* the nouns and verbs. This forces you to consider how word choice impacts meaning and rhythm while leveraging an existing structure.",

"**'Image Prompt' Collection:**  Create a digital mood board (Pinterest, Google Docs) of 5-10 compelling images.  For each image, write a *fragment* of a poem (a line, a phrase, a short stanza).  Later, weave these fragments together into a cohesive piece.",

"**'Constraints-Based' Poem:**  Force creative limitations. For example: Write a poem using only single-syllable words, or one where each line must start with a different letter of the alphabet. This encourages inventive language and problem-solving.",

"**'Voice Swap' Exercise:** Choose a poem written in a style very different from your own.  Rewrite it *in your own voice*, maintaining the core meaning but adapting the tone, language, and rhythm to reflect your personal style. This helps to expand your poetic range."
